The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to other foundational problems in mathematics. However, the category of Hilbert spaces and operators on it is not a well-behaved category, because it is not cartesian closed. This means that the category of Hilbert spaces is not a proper subcategory of itself. This makes it difficult to prove results about it. We provide a set of axioms that guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and operators on it is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This resolves a long-standing problem in the foundations of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in gene content and that the genome of the Myxozoa is one of the smallest reported in animals. Our findings suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is essential for nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, thus providing a proof of concept for the use of this strategy as a target for antiviral therapy. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral therapies against SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This study quantifies the magnitude of this yield variability and its consequences for global maize production and trade. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also underscore the importance of global cooperation in climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food-plant species is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore diets. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was sometimes greater between grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of large herbivores in the structure and function of grasslands. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and challenging problems in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar cosmic ray exposure ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. They also provide constraints for the formation of the first stars and the first galaxies in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. We provide a global reconstruction of the powered-artisanal fleet, which is essential to understand the evolution of the global fishing fleet. Our results highlight the importance of artisanal fisheries in the global fishing fleet and the need for sustainable management of these fisheries. The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit the reproductive output of mammals. We find that the greatest limiting factor is maternal metabolic power, rather than resource availability. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the evolution of domestication and allonursing may have been driven by the increase in maternal metabolic power rather than the increase in resource availability. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellar cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain and spinal cord. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons from α-syn toxicity in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to treat MSA and other α-synucleinopathies. This study also highlights the potential of VX-765 to be used in combination with other therapies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and each cell is specialized to perform a specific function. The endothelium is also composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other to form a network. The network is responsible for integrating information from multiple sources and coordinating the endothelium’s responses. The network is also responsible for the rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells. This study reveals the nature of the communication network and its design. The network is found to be highly efficient in both local and global communication. The design of the network is found to be effective for the control of cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health challenge, and the need for timely data has been critical for understanding the pandemic and for responding to it. We present the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, including traditional signals from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as well as many auxiliary signals that are extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data and software are available to the public, and we hope that this platform will be useful for tracking the pandemic and for empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric communication between the two gates. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This study provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the existence of closed-state inactivation in K+ channels. This study provides a structural explanation for the existence of closed-state inactivation in K+ channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in health and disease. The role of the anaerobic gut fungi in this ecosystem is not well understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products biosynthetic potential of four representative anaerobic gut fungi. The results support the hypothesis that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This study also provides a resource of genes and proteins that could be used to engineer novel natural products. This work represents a step toward understanding the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to contribute to the natural products biosynthetic potential of the gut microbiome. This knowledge could be used to develop novel therapeutics and biotechnologies.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness of high-anxious individuals is associated with the ability to prevent the development of a subordinate status in a social encounter. Our findings indicate that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our results also highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior.

The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of mechanical devices with complex behaviors is still a challenging task. Here, we propose a synthesis, fabrication, and assembly strategy to design and fabricate mechanical devices with complex behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The inverse design is performed by a digital model that is constructed by a large number of nodes and elements. The inverse design is then used to synthesize the composite structures, which are fabricated by multimaterial printing. The fabricated structures are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be used to design and fabricate mechanical devices with complex behaviors for a wide range of applications. The strategy can also be extended to design and fabricate mechanical devices with complex behaviors in a programmable way.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factors BCL11A and GATA-1. The role of heterochronic let-7 miRNAs in this process has been studied in mice, but the situation in humans is unclear. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is down-regulated in human fetal erythroid tissues and that IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of hemoglobin expression in erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have implications for the development of hemoglobin therapies for sickle cell anemia and other hemoglobinopathies. The results also suggest that the heterochronic let-7 pathway may be a target for chronoregulation in other tissues.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are effective in lowering blood pressure, but their long-term use is associated with the development of heart failure. The molecular mechanisms of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor complex, which is involved in vascular remodeling. Our findings may help to explain the adverse effects of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of older forests and the birds that depend on them. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older forests. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is why it is necessary to identify promising candidates as early as possible. In this study, we present a computational approach to identify promising acylide antibiotics, which can be used to develop new antibiotics. We show that our approach is able to identify the best candidate for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. The best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training examples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than other architectures, and with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes it easier to train the networks with a large number of training examples. The proposed architecture is also able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than other architectures. This makes it easier to train the networks with a large number of training examples.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The shift in hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT) is consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The MPT is associated with a dramatic change in the frequency of extreme droughts, which may have contributed to the rapid diversification of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. The hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species. This study provides a unique insight into the role of hydroclimate variability in the evolution of the Earth system.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are not well understood. Here we compare the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. We found that reading an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use to optimize the health and safety of the user. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas magnetic grains is consistent with terrestrial Os, and that the spherules from Pennsylvania are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Less)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is more complex than previously thought. Our findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, and we found that the origin of beetles and angiosperms coincided with the first appearance of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of beetles and their role in the biosphere.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Less)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural ecologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to expectations, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, we find that the size of the population may actually have a negative effect on CCE. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This may have important implications for the evolution of technology in human societies. Our results also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of culture in the evolution of complex systems. (Less)

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to AD. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the increased risk of AD associated with APOE4. They also provide a molecular mechanism for the increased risk of AD associated with APOE4.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase is the first nucleus, and then the hcp phase is formed from the bcc phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. They also provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. This work may help us understand the origin of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. They also highlight the need to develop effective treatments for marijuana abusers.

The human brain’s language system is the most studied cognitive system in neuroscience. However, the brain’s language processing mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network models of language comprehension, which are trained on a large corpus of human sentences, also predict neural responses in the human brain to sentences in a large independent dataset. This suggests that the brain’s language system is tuned to predict the next word in a sequence. This finding provides computational and neuroscientifically explicit evidence for a fundamental role of prediction in the human language system. It also suggests that the language system may be tuned to the predictions of the entire sequence, rather than to the current word alone. This may have important implications for theories of language processing and language acquisition. It also raises the possibility that artificial neural networks may one day help us understand the human brain’s language system.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why DL works, and why it is so successful. One of the main reasons is that DL is a black box, and it is difficult to understand how it works. In this paper, we show that the black box of DL can be opened by understanding the relationship between stability and approximation. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a neural network. This is a fundamental result that explains the success of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of the population to comply with the necessary measures. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the flaws of this experiment and show that it is not only a poor example of experimental design but also supports the conclusion of the experiment.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it continues to afflict humans. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, which is characterized by the presence of a large number of lymphocytes in the skin, is still unknown. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of diffuse lepromatous leprosy, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause disease. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of leprosy and its causative agents. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum systems is a central topic of current research. The entanglement dynamics is usually studied by means of numerical simulations, which are, however, limited to a few time steps. In this work, we develop a theoretical framework to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems. Our approach is based on the integrability of the model, which allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics exactly in the space–time scaling limit. We apply our approach to the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our results provide a general framework to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine strain was developed by recoding the viral genome with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine was shown to be highly protective in hamsters, and the results of a phase I/II clinical trial in humans are expected in the near future. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a major step forward in the fight against the pandemic. The results of this study are a testament to the scientific and medical community’s ability to work together to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. We are hopeful that this vaccine will be available to the public in the near future.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks, including the Black Death (1347–1353), which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways, including the inhalation of infectious droplets by humans and rodents, and the bite of infected fleas by humans and other mammals. Here, we describe a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of the disease.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of evolution, has been less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also not the same in birds and mammals. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is more complex and involves multiple shifts in the scaling of brain neurons. These shifts are associated with the evolution of cognitive abilities. Our results have important implications for the study of the evolution of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate cell movement. They are also the targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are key regulators of cell motility. However, how ADF/cofilin proteins sever actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin proteins bind to and sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We find that the mechanical state of the filament, such as its curvature or twist, can enhance or hinder severing. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin proteins sever actin filaments in a physiological context. They also provide a platform for the development of new tools to study the mechanical regulation of ADF/cofilin-mediated processes in cells. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-processing regions and greater hunger and desire for food and food-approach behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose and may contribute to the high incidence of obesity in the United States. The findings also suggest that the effects of fructose on appetite may be mediated, at least in part, by the brain’s reward system. This may explain why some people are more sensitive to the appetite-suppressing effects of fructose than others. The findings have implications for the development of strategies to combat obesity. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genetic history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. They also suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates the information into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only RNAs that are translated. Messenger RNA modifications can also have profound effects on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of one modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest effect on the translation of a single mRNA sequence. We also show that the presence of Ψ can increase the rate of protein synthesis from some mRNAs. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA sequences can have a significant impact on the translation of the protein encoded by that mRNA. This study provides insight into the role that mRNA modifications can play in the translation of proteins. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounders, and they are also robust over time, indicating that the feeling of being worthwhile is associated with positive outcomes over the long term. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is a major driver of body size in mammals. We use a model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases worldwide. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a major contributor to the severity of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the mouse airway cell model recapitulates the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus in primary cells, and that the innate immune response of infected cells is a major contributor to the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the environment in order to survive. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin pili to sense the environment. This mechanochemical sensing mechanism is used to regulate the activity of pili, which in turn regulates the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. This mechanochemical sensing mechanism is a unique example of a bacterial sensing system that uses the mechanical activity of a surface adhesin to sense the environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of insecticides in particular has been associated with a decline in aquatic biodiversity. However, the risk of pesticide contamination to surface water has not been comprehensively assessed on a global scale. We provide a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and their effects on aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. We recommend worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. Our findings have implications for the protection of surface water quality and the conservation of aquatic biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in the environment. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study also demonstrates the utility of free-living animals as sentinels for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in the environment. These discoveries have implications for the conservation of wildlife and the health of humans and other animals. Our findings have implications for the conservation of wildlife and the health of humans and other animals.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of large dams, and the solutions that are needed to move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to the presence of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and cell death. However, the role of Aβ in the earliest stages of AD is unclear. Here, we demonstrate that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the production of a variety of potent immune factors by neurons. These factors correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. We also show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have implications for the development of novel therapeutics for AD. (Show more)

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of the domestic chicken and its integration into the economy. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The structure is formed by the interaction of many amino acid side chains, and the folding is a dynamic process that involves the exchange of hydrogen bonds. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps, but the cellular functions of these molecules have remained elusive. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which is inactivated by Np4, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli cells experiencing stress. We demonstrate that RppH prefers decapping Np4-capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and that the enzyme uses a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapply other RNAs. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study provides insight into the functions of Np4 and the mechanisms by which decapping enzymes can be repurposed to regulate gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune dysfunction that characterizes sepsis is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Tregs), which are known to contribute to the pathogenesis of sepsis. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We demonstrate that arginine supplementation is more efficient than citrulline supplementation in restoring T cell function and proliferation, reducing the expansion of MDSCs, and decreasing the expansion of Tregs. These results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing clinical trials of citrulline in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the deep subsurface. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a key step toward understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This work is a first step toward a global census of the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system self-adjusts its dynamics to the environment in such a way that the system is critical, in the sense of the central limit theorem, most of the time. The most prominent example of SOC is the sandpile model, which is a discrete model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are limited. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that its electronic properties can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The findings also provide insights into the stability of diamond under mechanical strain. The findings are expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based technologies.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the health of the host is well established. However, the role of the host in the health of the microbiota is less understood. The host immune system is a key regulator of the microbiota, and the host immune response is often the first line of defense against invading pathogens. The host immune system is also a source of antimicrobial peptides, which are a class of peptides that are highly diverse in sequence and structure. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and demonstrate its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work illustrates the potential of a structurally unique NCR peptide as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also highlights the potential of the host immune system as a source of antimicrobial peptides that can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work may lead to the development of a new class of spray-on fungistat/fungicides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and we identify a set of female-derived proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of particular interest to the scientific community studying the male–female reproductive axis. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to prevent bleeding. The A1 domain of VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and is thought to be regulated by platelet flow. We show that force can regulate the A1 domain, and that this regulation is important for platelet binding. We also show that the regulation is similar to that of GPIbα, suggesting that the A1 domain is regulated by the same mechanism. This mechanism is important for the function of VWF in the blood.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database is publicly available and can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models due to the complexity of the interaction. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is a new instrument that can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. This instrument is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. Here, we introduce the dual-FOV HSRL and demonstrate its capability to investigate ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This instrument is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing paleotemperatures based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the molecular switches that control ion flow. They open and close their pore gates, and the rate of channel opening/closing determines the channel’s conductance. The K+ channel KCNK10 (formerly known as KCNK9) is a member of the K+ channel family that lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the KCNK10 channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the KCNK10 channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channel gating and inactivation. It also provides a molecular mechanism for the KCNK10 channel’s unique properties. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. We show that the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the physical properties of the RBC, increasing the cytoskeletal tension and reducing the bending modulus of the cell membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This study provides a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This study also provides a potential target for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we study the mechanical properties of diamond under strain and show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. We also study the conditions for phase transition to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based technologies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of humidity in influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also provide a rationale for the development of humidity-based strategies to control influenza virus transmission and disease. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to unfold sequentially, word by word. However, linguists have long argued that the brain’s underlying syntactic structure is more complex, involving a tree of nested phrases. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly increases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, suggesting that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrase structures. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and cell fate decisions. It is also a target of cancer therapy. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique opportunity to study the role of the two scaffolds in the pathway and to understand the mechanisms of redundancy. It also provides a model for studying the role of redundant genes in general. This study may also have implications for cancer therapy.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is poorly understood. Here we characterize a brain circuit that is critical for this process. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that dopamine lesions or dopamine receptor antagonists block this effect. We further show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat for the remainder of a 60-s stimulation period. Finally, we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat for the remainder of a 60-s stimulation period. We also show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat for the remainder of a 60-s stimulation period. We also show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat for the remainder of a 60-s stimulation period. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for crop growth and productivity, and the global population is expected to increase by 2.5 billion by 2050. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop sustainable solutions to increase crop productivity. One promising approach is to engineer the plant–microbe interaction to control the activity of the nitrogen-fixing symbiont. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of such an approach, by engineering the plant and the symbiont to interact in a synthetic manner. We show that the nitrogen-fixing symbiont can be controlled to fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant, and that the interaction is prevented from occurring with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be applied to other nitrogen-fixing symbioses and to other crops. It could also be applied to other microbes, such as biocontrol agents, to control their activity in the environment.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major cause of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is losing forest at an accelerating rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to improve the effectiveness of remote-sensed alerts and to provide incentives for community members to act on those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their senses to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is a highly sensitive acoustic sensor that can detect the motion of its own threads, and it can localize the source of the sound. The spider can also supersize its web to increase its acoustic sensitivity. This provides a unique model for studying the sensing of fluid flows, and for the design of novel acoustic flow detectors. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of sensing and the design of acoustic devices. This study also provides a unique model for studying the sensing of fluid flows. (Less)

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle, and the relative importance of different sources is poorly understood. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions, and the additional benefits of reducing nonfossil anthropogenic sources. We find that fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality and 70% of the aerosol cooling. Our results show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all anthropogenic sources 0.73(±0.03) °C of warming, thus limiting global warming to 2 °C. This can be achieved by a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. Our findings are important for the design of climate and health policies. They also highlight the importance of aerosols in the climate system and the need for a reduction of anthropogenic emissions of particles.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the availability of a safe and efficacious vaccine at a low cost is critical. We report the design, construction, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern, and presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD variant provides a potential platform for a low-cost, high-volume vaccine that could be rapidly deployed globally. This work is a step toward a solution to the global vaccine access crisis. (Less)

The role of ALK in development and cancer is well established. However, the ligand(s) for human ALK are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are able to activate human ALK and that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in neural crest development. Our results provide in vivo evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKL family receptors in neural crest development and suggest that secreted ALKALs are potential ligands for human ALK. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK in cancer and development and may lead to the development of ALK inhibitors with improved selectivity.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The pathogen has caused numerous epidemics and pandemics, with devastating consequences for human populations. The timing of its emergence is still debated, and the available evidence is based on a small number of genomes. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, and show that the pathogen underwent a period of rapid diversification and dispersal during this time. Our data also reveal the presence of a previously unknown form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which may have been the result of a recent introduction from the Caucasus. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of plague throughout human history. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in explaining men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. The conversion of grasslands to croplands has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere, but the potential to mitigate this carbon loss through the restoration of grasslands remains largely unexplored. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can sequester carbon in the soil and increase the potential for carbon storage in the future. Our results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. This study provides a unique example of the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and highlights the need to restore grasslands to mitigate the effects of agricultural land use change on the global carbon cycle.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, and several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of this trait in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings provide molecular evidence for the convergence of this trait and demonstrate that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work contributes to our understanding of the chemical basis for the evolution of nectar color and its role in the evolution of mutualistic plant–pollinator interactions.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present genome-wide data from a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This study highlights the importance of the study of the female genome in the reconstruction of the history of Europe.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that the receptor usage of the two bat coronaviruses is opposite to each other, and that the two bat coronaviruses have different abilities to use host cellular proteases for efficient entry into human cells. These results suggest that the two bat coronaviruses have adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. The findings are important for understanding the origin of MERS-CoV and the risk of HKU4 and HKU5 to cause human infections. They also suggest that the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses may be a promising target for the development of antiviral drugs. These results may also have implications for the development of vaccines against HKU4 and HKU5. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogen causing undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA from 489 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including dengue virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and chikungunya virus. Our findings highlight the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the impact of emerging epidemics. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings.
