The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is replicated by the polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand DNA synthesis. This study also provides a platform for the development of novel therapeutics that target the pol δ holoenzyme. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but the process is inefficient. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that led to the improvement of the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA-based cell. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage, and there is no specific treatment. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately.

The role of metal micronutrients in fungal growth and metabolism is well established, but the existence of fungal natural products that bind and regulate metal homeostasis is less well known. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC isocyanide products suggest a role for these metabolites in the regulation of fungal interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a previously unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in metal homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. They also provide a basis for the development of novel antifungal agents. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present-day temperature and pressure of Mars. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and primary amorphous precipitates, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is also significant because it provides evidence for a history of aqueous activity on Mars, including the potential for acidic leaching and the formation of secondary minerals.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is expected to increase in the future. We show that the geographic distribution of frost-sensitive species is changing in response to the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to mitigate the economic impact of frost damage. Our results also provide a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of frost events and the role of frost in the diversification of plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. We found that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells, but that the developmental fate of Th17 precursors was dependent on the expression of the transcription factors T-bet and Stat4. Th17 cells were required for the development of colitis, but only if they had transitioned to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may contribute to the development of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the developmental origins of Th17 cells may lead to the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells responsible for generating movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins that are essential for motor neuron function. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will accelerate ALS research and development of therapies. This method will also enable rapid production of induced pluripotent stem cells from living ALS patients, which will allow for the study of ALS pathogenesis and the development of cell-based therapies. This will be of great benefit to ALS patients.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the success of the vector in transmitting infectious diseases. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick I. scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the vector. We demonstrate that the antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of the gut microbiota, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and the role of the microbiota in vector competence. This knowledge will be important for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. This new taxon shows that the short tail of birds evolved from a fusion of the shoulder and chest bones, a feature that is plesiomorphic for birds. The mosaic evolution of this feature and the presence of a short tail in basal birds is likely related to the development of flight.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to blend in with their surroundings. The most common color is green, which is produced by the pigment chlorophyll. However, some vertebrates have a distinctive color, which is called chlorosis. The biochemical basis of chlorosis is poorly understood, and the evolution of this phenomenon is not well-known. Here, we show that the occurrence of chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that this evolution is driven by the presence of a class of serpins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main component of chlorophyll. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study contributes to our understanding of the evolution of color and the function of serpins.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse, and are thought to be enriched in hypoxic regions of the tumor microenvironment. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) residues on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in hypoxic breast cancer cells, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are tumorigenic and enriched for BCSC features. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used, but others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many Bibles were made from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine parchment does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The cause of the extinction is uncertain, but the timing of the carbon cycle reorganization, the timing of the extinction, and the timing of ecosystem recovery are all controlled by the timing of the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model for the boundary developed here will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most common mutation in the virus currently circulating in the population. We have determined the cryo-electron microscopy structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the D614G conformation and compared it to the G614 conformation. We find that the G614 spike is more open and may facilitate receptor binding. This study provides a structural basis for the increased transmissibility of the G614 mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections indicate that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, and the Latino−White gap will decrease by more than 3 y, implying that the United States is likely to see a reversal of the progress made in reducing racial disparities in life expectancy since 2006. These findings have implications for the future of health equity in the United States.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two central properties that can be calculated for any atom in the periodic table. We show that the chemical hardness and electronegativity of atoms decrease with pressure, and we show that the pseudo–noble-gas elements Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron donors, while the pseudo–metal elements Fe, Co, Rh, and Ir are electron acceptors. We show that the chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom can be used to predict the chemical behavior of the compound formed by the atom with another atom. We believe that our work will be of interest to the chemistry community, and we hope that it will be used to predict and explain the chemistry of compounds under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the sign and magnitude of these changes are uncertain, and the potential impacts on the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity and the carbon cycle, using a coupled climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is one of the best-studied examples of a mutualism in which the host provides a nutrient to the symbiont, which in turn provides a benefit to the host. We show here that the host-derived nutrient is not essential for the survival of the symbiont, but is required for the persistence of the symbiosis. We also show that the host-derived nutrient is cyclically delivered to the symbiotic organ just before dusk, and that the catabolism of this nutrient is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ that is necessary for the symbiont to produce light. This study provides a new example of how the provision of a nutrient to a symbiotic partner can have a direct effect on the physiology of the symbiont, and on the stability of the mutualism. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic partners may be a more common mechanism for regulating the activities of symbioses, and for maintaining the stability of these relationships, than previously thought.

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with advances in word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. Our method can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identification of the exact origin of the disease is a central question in the study of the Black Death. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics in Europe were the result of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results provide evidence for the existence of climate-driven reintroductions of the plague bacterium into European harbors, which may have contributed to the establishment of the disease in Europe.

Asteroids are a keystone species in the Northeast Pacific Ocean, playing a crucial role in the ecosystem. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself. The virus is also present in the past museum specimens, suggesting that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge in the treatment of this disease. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are able to target AML stem cells and that this antibody is able to block IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results provide a proof of concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP in the treatment of other diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia, with a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genetic history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for the study of the genetic history of the Indian Ocean islands. This study will be a valuable resource for the study of the human history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean islands.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) and to base pair with the adjacent genes cadA and galE. We found that the RNA also interacts with the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. We propose that the RNA and protein function to regulate carbon utilization in response to the availability of glycerol. The protein interferes with the action of the RNA, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple biological processes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Less)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the assessments of a large number of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the CPC survey exhibits long-term stability and can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields with high accuracy. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the design of early warning systems for agricultural production anomalies, and for the development of agricultural monitoring systems that can be used to support food security and sustainable agriculture.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces firing rates. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to climate warming is a key uncertainty in predicting the magnitude of future changes in the global carbon cycle. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a lack of fossil evidence. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis itself. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process may have contributed to the emergence of the most complex life forms on Earth. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in southwestern South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. Our findings are relevant to water managers and policy makers in the region. They also highlight the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” provides a unique opportunity to study the conditions under which quasicrystals are formed. We report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the glass of the Trinity test, and we show that the discovery of this quasicrystal is itself a product of the extreme conditions of the test.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Here, we show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a subunit of the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a major role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting a phase-specific role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases and autoimmune diseases.
