California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Our findings have important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere. They also have implications for climate model evaluation and for the interpretation of climate model experiments with and without anthropogenic forcings. Our findings are consistent with the view that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes and the causal pathways is a major challenge. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Show more)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people do react more strongly to negative news content, but that individual-level variation is considerable. This work also highlights the potential for more positive news content to be more widely consumed, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and dysregulation of its function is associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and STIM2 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and in Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease of hematopoietic and skeletal muscle. We also identify mutations in the ORAI1 channel pore-forming protein that result in the suppression of slow Ca2+-dependent inactivation of the CRAC channel, and in the Stormorken-like syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spreading of aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, where they are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is increasingly recognized, but the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to inhibit the host immune response and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic diseases and may help to inform the development of strategies to prevent future outbreaks. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer growth in mice, and that the enzyme is essential for colon cancer growth in vivo. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor formate rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a platform for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and for the development of a metabolic target for cancer therapy. This work also provides a metabolic target for cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a hallmark of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a molecular explanation for the presence of inclusions in ALS and suggests that the disease is caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, which can be used to study quantum many-body physics. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light, which can be used to study quantum optics. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light, which can be used to study quantum optics.

The origin of the Ceratophyllum clade of aquatic angiosperms is poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant previously overlooked, provides new insights into the origin of this clade. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, and the two are more closely related to each other than to any other angiosperm. Montsechia is also the earliest known angiosperm with a true root system, a feature that is present in the Ceratophyllum clade and in some other aquatic angiosperms. The study of Montsechia also raises questions about the very early diversification of the Ceratophyllum clade, which is sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of the history of life on Earth. However, the evolution of viruses is difficult to study, as they are typically very small and difficult to isolate. Here we present the genomes of ancient viruses from human remains, which allow us to study the evolution of viruses in the past. We find that the evolution of B19V is much slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the emergence of the virus and the recombination event that led to the emergence of the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses can be preserved in ancient human remains, and that ancient viruses can be used to study the evolution of viruses in the past. This is important for our understanding of the history of life on Earth.

Sea level is rising, and the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the hypothesis that the climate system is warming, and the rate of sea level rise is increasing because of human activities. The rate of sea level rise is a key indicator of the magnitude of the sea-level contribution to the projected impacts of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that pain has increased more rapidly with age for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of an enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the role of crystallographic waters in the active site, and highlights the importance of the cofactor’s ability to tautomerize in the active site. This work demonstrates the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. This approach may be applicable to a wide range of enzymes, including those that are not amenable to X-ray crystallography. This work also highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed characterization of enzyme intermediates, which may be used to study enzyme mechanisms and to design inhibitors. This work provides a detailed characterization of an enzyme intermediate, which may be used to study enzyme mechanisms and to design inhibitors.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS-CoV infection, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued research into the development of antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This is particularly important in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The data presented here may also be of interest to the broader medical community, as the MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV viruses are related to the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We show that the glycan is provided to the squid only at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most vulnerable to infection. We also show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiosis. Finally, we show that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a more common mechanism for the regulation of the health of the tissues in which they reside than previously thought.

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The study also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a powerful predictor of student behavior and that students’ perceptions of teachers’ mindsets about discipline are a powerful predictor of their behavior. These findings have implications for the design of effective school interventions and for the development of effective school systems.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional mutagenesis induced by DNA alkylation remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of DNA alkylation on transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and lesion bypass routes. Our results provide mechanistic insights into the transcriptional mutagenesis induced by DNA alkylation. Furthermore, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, termed Pro-Gate loop, which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional mutagenesis induced by DNA alkylation. Our findings may help to develop novel strategies for the development of DNA alkylation-resistant anticancer drugs. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must first be cleaved by the spike (S) glycoproteins, which are secreted into the cell cytoplasm, and then be cleaved again to facilitate cell-membrane fusion. We found that the first cleavage steps are important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence, because they expand the cell types that are permissive for infection, and also because they determine the virions’ susceptibility to the host immune system. These findings suggest that the first S cleavage steps may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the environment, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices. We show that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a cafeteria by 40% without a detectable rebound effect. This is a simple intervention that could be implemented in many settings, and it could have a significant impact on the environment. Our results suggest that it is possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets. This is an important step toward achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex system. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and to study the impact of a potent MEK inhibitor on the surfaceome of each oncogene. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. However, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. Our findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that our findings will help election administrators make informed decisions about the implementation of vote-by-mail programs in the future.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to spread rapidly through the population, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be used to mediate immune suppression. This work provides insight into the molecular basis for the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) and its receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 in the cortex contributes to edema via AQP4. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations in the data, given that we have already selected the “best” associations. This is a problem of great practical importance, because it determines the power of statistical tests and the size of confidence intervals. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. Our work is a step toward a general theory of selective inference.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the conversion of primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is accompanied by the up-regulation of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and the expression of endothelial functional molecules, such as von Willebrand factor. ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETVECs for the development of vascular networks in regenerated organs may provide a solution for the shortage of vascularized tissues. These findings may lead to the development of a new strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of vascularized tissues. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases ALK and LTK are implicated in a variety of human cancers. Here, we use zebrafish as a model to study the physiological role of these receptors. We show that zebrafish augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized class of photoreceptors that are unique to the zebrafish. We also show that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the adult eye and body coloration. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a foundation for understanding the role of these receptors in the development of the zebrafish and other vertebrates. It also provides a model for studying the role of orphan RTKs in development and cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired insulin secretion. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective insulin secretion in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned ST

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of hosts, including humans, and cause severe diseases. The influenza A genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA fragments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting fragments. Our results indicate that viral RNA fragments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings could help to understand the mechanisms of influenza virus evolution and could provide a basis for the development of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a molecular basis for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis and may lead to the development of a new class of therapeutic agents for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the role of people in increasing the extent and severity of wildfire is largely unknown. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas with higher fuel moisture, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Our findings highlight the need for policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Our findings also highlight the need for policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that it will be useful to urban planners and policymakers.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. The ongoing bleaching events are a direct consequence of global warming and are expected to become more frequent and severe in the future. Our study shows that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is not a consequence of the bleaching process itself but rather a result of the interaction between the physiological and metabolic responses of the coral host and the altered nutrient cycling of the symbionts. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs under climate change. This may ultimately help us to conserve this unique and valuable ecosystem. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host–microbe interaction. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling in maintaining intestinal homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer patients. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to chemotherapy. We found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly useful for patients who are resistant to chemotherapy. Our findings also suggest that ROR1 may be a promising target for the development of combination therapies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in climate science. The role of volcanic eruptions in this event is also a matter of debate. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation was linked to a series of volcanic eruptions that occurred exactly at the time of the last glacial inception. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely contributed to the rapid climate changes that initiated the last deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a strong impact on climate and the atmosphere, and it helps to resolve the debate about the role of volcanic forcing in the last deglaciation. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, highlighting the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our results emphasize the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and the need to protect these ecosystems from degradation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are the key to achieve high capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with L

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury, a phenomenon that is thought to be due to the loss of the ability to regenerate during development. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more regenerative than previously thought.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a key component of the process by which genomes evolve. In this study, we describe the recombination landscape of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of a mouse model of recombination deficiency. We find that the recombination landscape of the flowering plant is similar to that of the mouse, suggesting that the recombination landscape of the mouse is a conserved feature of eukaryotes. This study provides a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which will be useful for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants and for understanding the genetic basis of flowering time in Mimulus.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of different brain regions fluctuates over time. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a set of reproducible patterns of connectivity, which are assumed to reflect the organization of the brain in health and disease. However, the validity of this assumption has not been tested in a large population of healthy subjects and patients. Here, we show that the dominant resting metabolic pattern in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this pattern is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Furthermore, we show that the dominant resting metabolic pattern is reduced in cognitive impairment in Alzheimer’s disease, but is already present in Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the resting brain and its functional organization. They also provide a method for the longitudinal assessment of the resting brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for proper translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery is important for understanding the function of 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes. It also has implications for the study of RNA modifications in general, because the NAD+ group is a common component of many natural chemical modifications. The NAD+ group is also found in the 5′ region of tRNA, and is essential for the function of this important class of RNA.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control in people with type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes can prevent the development of complications. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the risk of complications in people with diabetes are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia, and high glucose induces similar persistent hypomethylation at one of the differentially methylated loci in vitro. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory of intensive glucose control in people with diabetes. They also suggest that epigenetic changes at specific loci may be a potential biomarker for the long-term effects of intensive glucose control. This may help to explain the long-term benefits of intensive glucose control and may help to predict the risk of complications in people with diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective treatment options. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Less)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the contribution of these compounds to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be a valuable resource for the breeding of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of climate change. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change in the context of biodiversity loss, and they suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the design of conservation strategies and for the management of ecosystems under climate change. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, and its precise organization is critical for memory and navigation. The cell types that make up MEC are not well understood, partly because of the difficulty of studying them in freely behaving animals. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from MEC neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial memory, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, suggesting that they might form a distinct network. This study provides a powerful method for studying the organization of MEC neurons in freely moving animals and will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in memory and navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This may be of importance for the understanding of the evolution of flowering in plants. It also illustrates the importance of the study of parasites for understanding the evolution of flowering in plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The precise nature of the pathophysiology of this system is not fully understood, however, and the mechanisms by which dopamine-related function is impaired are not well delineated. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is likely to be important to dopamine-related function. We show that the dopamine-containing nigral system has a highly complex architecture, with striosomes, a newly identified subnucleus of the substantia nigra, that are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation, and the dopamine-containing dendron bouquets, which are likely to be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected, and may thus be a robust indicator of connection in social interaction.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate and are characterized by a unique morphology and physiology. The SAN is a highly specialized cell type that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plants, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) levels and defense gene expression. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses may be a key mechanism underlying the insect-protective effect of Si. These findings may help to elucidate the mechanism of Si-mediated insect resistance and provide insights into the potential of Si as a biocontrol agent. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We further show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces firing rates. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology community and will help in the development of plant biotechnology.

The impacts of nutrient loading on the world’s lakes and rivers are well documented, but the role of small tributaries is largely unknown. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to large lakes comes from small tributaries, but that these tributaries are also the most biologically available. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may play a greater role in driving coastal eutrophication than previously thought. This may be particularly true for lakes that are surrounded by agricultural landscapes, where the majority of small tributaries are located. Our results highlight the need to consider the role of small tributaries in nutrient loading to lakes and the potential for coastal eutrophication. This may be particularly important in the context of climate change, as small tributaries are more likely to be affected by changes in precipitation and runoff. Our findings have implications for the management of nutrient loading to lakes and the protection of valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale thermodynamic equilibrium in the early universe is explained by the fact that the universe is finely tuned to a particular state that extremizes the entropy.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We use a dynamic causal model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same synaptic parameters that are altered by NMDAR-Ab may be a target for therapeutic intervention. This study offers a mechanistic explanation for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbations is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. We also show that the event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. Our results provide insights into the history of carbon perturbations and the history of global warming. They also provide a case study for the potential impacts of climate change on the deep ocean. This study provides a unique perspective on the history of carbon perturbations and the history of global warming.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification may be most effective in reducing deforestation in areas with low forest cover and high fire risk. However, the effectiveness of certification in reducing deforestation in these areas is likely to be limited by the fact that most certified plantations are small and fragmented. Our results also suggest that certification may be most effective in reducing deforestation in areas with low forest cover and high fire risk. However, the effectiveness of certification in reducing deforestation in these areas is likely to be limited by the fact that most certified plantations are small and fragmented.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, of which the EXO70 subunit is the most important. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved in plants and animals, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, or by multiple interacting sex determination alleles, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a fish, the cichlid Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the multiple alleles of this fish produce a modular system of sexual polymorphism, where the same genetic locus can produce both sexes and secondary sexual characteristics. This modular system of sexual polymorphism provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work also provides a case study of the effects of sex determination on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble molecules that are oxidized and degraded by reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of lipid-soluble molecules that are oxidized and degraded by reactive oxygen species. We found that Fe levels in the retina impact the oxidation and degradation of a lipid-soluble molecule that is a component of the bisretinoid signaling system. These findings have implications for the understanding of retinal diseases in which oxidative stress and lipid-soluble molecule accumulation are implicated in disease pathogenesis. They also have implications for the development of therapies that target the oxidation and degradation of lipid-soluble molecules in the retina. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in shaping the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to occur throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in the cnidarian siphonophores is not a dead end, and that specialization can be maintained by the evolution of morphological innovations in separate structures. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological innovations in the diversification of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the modern human hand is a key area of research, with the emergence of a suite of derived features in the thumb, wrist, and radial carpometacarpal joints being a key evolutionary event. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this suite in the hominin fossil record. The fossil also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study thus provides a key contribution to our understanding of the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer growth in mice, and that the cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a platform for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and for the development of a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized, despite a growing body of literature showing that having access to these landscapes can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. In this study, we show that deforestation over a 5-y period led to a reduction in household fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation led to an increase in consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study finds a causal link between deforestation and people’s dietary quality, and the results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets. We believe that this study will be of interest to researchers and policy makers interested in the role of forests in improving people’s diets.

The agricultural revolution has been driven by mechanization, which has increased the capacity of farm machinery and thus the productivity of arable land. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights, which have increased the risks of subsoil compaction. We show that the risks of subsoil compaction have increased over the course of modern mechanization, and that the total area of arable land with chronic subsoil compaction risk now exceeds 20% of the global cropland. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these prehistoric giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Our findings call for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This may help to mitigate the risks of subsoil compaction and ensure the sustainability of modern agriculture. (Less)
